HI.notes:
House Bill 2181: Creates sweeping exemptions allowing people and businesses to discriminate against transgender people and same-sex couples based on their religious or moral beliefs.

House Bill 2532: Creates sweeping exemptions allowing people and businesses to discriminate against transgender people and same-sex couples based on their religious or moral beliefs.

IA.notes: No data or citations for this state. Please submit information by clicking 'Contact' at the bottom of the page.

ID.notes: No data or citations for this state. Please submit information by clicking 'Contact' at the bottom of the page.

IL.notes: House Bill 4474: Requires students to use single-sex facilities (like restrooms and changing rooms) according to their sex assigned at birth, and requires schools to segregate all multi-user facilities by sex. Creates restrictions on when trans students can use single-user restrooms. Re-referred to Rules Committee on 4/8/16.

IN.notes:
House Bill 1079: Makes it a class B misdemeanor (a crime) for anyone above age 10 to use a restroom that does not match their sex assigned at birth.

Senate Bill 35: Requires students to use single-sex facilities (like restrooms and changing rooms) according to their sex assigned at birth, and requires schools to segregate all multi-user facilities by sex. Makes it a class A misdemeanor (a crime) for an adult to use single-sex facilities that does not match their sex assigned at birth in public buildings.

KS.notes:
House Bill 2737: Requires K-12 and postsecondary students to use single-sex facilities (like restrooms and locker rooms) according to their sex assigned at birth. Any student who runs into a trans person in a restroom or locker room can sue the school for $2500 for each time they saw the trans person there.

Senate Bill 513: Requires K-12 and postsecondary students to use single-sex facilities (like restrooms and locker rooms) according to their sex assigned at birth. Any student who runs into a trans person in a restroom or locker room can sue the school for $2500 for each time they saw the trans person there.

KY.notes:
House Bill 364: Requires students to use single-sex facilities (like restrooms and changing rooms) according to their sex assigned at birth.

Senate Bill 76 would have restricted trans students' access to bathrooms, locker rooms, and other gender-segreated facilities on school campuses. Failed 3/25/2015

LA.notes: No data or citations for this state. Please submit information by clicking 'Contact' at the bottom of the page.

MA.notes:
House Bill 1320: Requires people to access single-sex facilities (like restrooms, changing rooms and living accommodations) and educational, athletic and therapeutic programs according to their “anatomical sex.”

Bill H.4253 "grants all persons admission to and the full enjoyment of [...] public accommodation or other entity consistent with the person's gender identity."

MD.notes: No data or citations for this state. Please submit information by clicking 'Contact' at the bottom of the page.

ME.notes: No data or citations for this state. Please submit information by clicking 'Contact' at the bottom of the page.

MI.notes: No data or citations for this state. Please submit information by clicking 'Contact' at the bottom of the page.

MN.notes:
House File 3396: Prohibits schools, employers and businesses from letting trans people use restrooms, changing rooms and other facilities according to their gender identity.

Senate File 3002: Prohibits schools, employers and businesses from letting trans people use restrooms, changing rooms and other facilities according to their gender identity.

MO.notes:
House Bill 1624: Requires students to use single-sex facilities (like restrooms and changing rooms) according to their sex assigned at birth (unless they get permission by the school's superintendent) and requires schools to segregate all multi-user facilities by sex.

House Bill 1847: Requires all public restrooms (except for single-stall restrooms) to be segregated by gender.

House Bill 2303: Requires students to use single-sex facilities (like restrooms and changing rooms) according to their sex assigned at birth. Allows some trans students to use empty single-sex facilities when accompanied by a school administrator.

Senate Bill 720: What it would do: Requires schools to make all multi-user facilities male-only or female-only, and requires students to use single-sex facilities according to their sex assigned at birth. Creates restrictions on when trans students can use single-user restrooms.

MS.notes: House Bill 1258: Makes it a felony to use a restroom that doesn't match someone's sex assigned assigned at birth, punishable by up to $5000 in fines and 5 years in prison, unless they can provide medical evidence that they've been on hormones for over a year.

MT.notes: No data or citations for this state. Please submit information by clicking 'Contact' at the bottom of the page.

NC.notes:
Feb 2016: Asheville passed a city ordinance that protects transgender people using public bathrooms that correspond with their gender identity.

Mar 2016: State legislature passed a bathroom bill (barring) on 3/23/2016 that overrides local laws.

OH.notes: No data or citations for this state. Please submit information by clicking 'Contact' at the bottom of the page.

OK.notes:
House Bill 3049: Requires students to use restrooms and locker rooms according to their sex assigned at birth (based on "physical difference" or chromosomes).

Senate Bill 1014: Makes it illegal for people to use restrooms that don't match their “biological gender.”

Senate Bill 1323: Requires sex-specific student facilities to be segregated according to anatomy at birth, and withholds State Aid funds from schools that have sex-specific facilities and do not respond to a complaint by a parent or student according to the bill's requirements.

RI.notes: No data or citations for this state. Please submit information by clicking 'Contact' at the bottom of the page.

SC.notes: Senate Bill 1203: Requires people to use restrooms in schools and other buildings on public property according to their sex assigned at birth and prohibits local governments from adopting different policies.

SD.notes: House Bill 1008: Requires students to use single-sex facilities (like restrooms and changing rooms) according to their sex assigned at birth and requires schools to segregate all multi-user facilities by sex. Creates restrictions on when trans students can use single-user restrooms.

TN.notes:
House Bill 2414: Requires students in public schools, including public colleges and universities, to use restrooms and locker rooms according to their sex assigned at birth.

Senate Bill 2387: Requires students in public schools, including public colleges and universities, to use restrooms and locker rooms according to their sex assigned at birth.

UT.notes: No data or citations for this state. Please submit information by clicking 'Contact' at the bottom of the page.

VA.notes:
House Bill 663: Requires students to use single-sex facilities (like restrooms and changing rooms) according to their sex assigned at birth and imposes a fine for violation. Requires schools to segregate all multi-user facilities by sex. Creates restrictions on when trans students can use single-user restrooms.

House Bill 781: Requires students to use single-sex facilities (like restrooms and changing rooms) according to their sex assigned at birth and imposes a fine for violation. Requires schools to segregate all multi-user facilities by sex. Creates restrictions on when trans students can use single-user restrooms.

VT.notes: No data or citations for this state. Please submit information by clicking 'Contact' at the bottom of the page.

WA.notes:
House Bill 2589: Amends the state's nondiscrimination law to away trans' people ability to use single-sex facilities according to gender identity. Allows private and public entities to bar people from single-sex facilities based on their anatomy.

House Bill 2935: Repeals a regulation that allows trans people to access facilities according to their gender identity and forbids the Washington Human Rights Commission from making any more regulations about access to single-sex facilities.

House Bill 2941: Requires students to use restrooms according to sex assigned at birth.

Senate Bill 6443: Repeals a regulation that allows trans people to access facilities according to their gender identity and forbids the Washington Human Rights Commission from making any more regulations about access to single-sex facilities.

Senate Bill 6548: Amends the state's nondiscrimination law to away trans' people ability to use single-sex facilities according to gender identity. Allows private and public entities to bar people from single-sex facilities based on their anatomy.

WI.notes:
Assembly Bill 469: Requires students to use single-sex facilities (like restrooms and changing rooms) according to their sex assigned at birth, and requires schools to segregate all multi-user facilities by sex. Creates restrictions on when trans students can use single-user restrooms.

Senate Bill 582: Requires students to use single-sex facilities (like restrooms and changing rooms) according to their sex assigned at birth.
